results.title: Land of gold
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Peach’s gold”.
Using dramatised re-enactments as well as historical footage, Bill Peach investigates the economic crash of the 1890s and the exhaustion of the goldfields at Ballarat and Bendigo. He describes how the less well known but far more productive goldfields at Coolgardie and Kalgoorlie rescued Australia from the depths of depression and continued to contribute to the country’s economy up to the early 1980s.

results.title: Finders keepers
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Peach’s gold”.
Employing dramatised re-enactments, as well as historical footage, Bill Peach presents a history of the discovery of the first lucrative goldfield in Australia. The discovery of the goldfield near Bathurst in New South Wales, was made by Edward Hargraves, John Lister and William Tom.

results.title: Fingers
results.creator_credit: James Toback, George Barrie and Brut Films
results.brief_description: A talented pianist is placed under enormous mental strain, caught between a rarefied world and the sadistic, violent milieu of the mafia. Harvey Keitel plays Jimmy Angelelli, a man who yearns for perfection as a performer but at the same time is pressurised by his abusive father to become involved in the family business of organised crime. Unfortunately Jimmy has an incendiary temper, which makes him ill suited for the work, and when it comes to his anger and frustration, he is without boundaries. Cruising the grimy New York streets with his noisy boom box, playing an incessant round of pop hits, Jimmy is dangerously unhinged and his mental state and grasp on reality, slowly erodes. James Toback’s (Two girls and a guy, Black and white) debut feature is a fascinating view of a man at war with himself and features a stunning lead performance by Keitel. Like Scorsese’s early work (such as Who’s That Knocking at My Door? and Mean Streets) Toback utilises the New York setting to explore one man’s mental deterioration, a theme echoed two years earlier in “Taxi Driver”. Cast also includes Tisa Farrow, Jim Brown and Michael Vincente Gazzo.

results.title: Finding Forrester [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Gus Van Sant, Laurence Mark, Rhonda Tollefson, Sean Connery, Columbia Pictures, Fountainbridge Films and Laurence Mark Productions
results.brief_description: Basketball star and ‘C’ student Jamal Wallace (Rob Brown) surprises everyone except himself when his amazing writing abilities and basketball prowess attract the attention of a Manhattan private school. Outside his old school in the Bronx lives a reclusive old man (Sean Connery) who Jamal meets when, on a dare from his friends, enters the building and is frightened when he encounters the man the students call, “The Window”. In his haste to escape he leaves behind his backpack, only to have it returned the following day with comments written in his personal writing notebooks. Jamal returns to the apartment and slowly wins the trust of the old man who convinces him to attend the new school and learn all he can about himself. Inspired by his new mentor, he agrees, and it is at this school that he discovers that the short-tempered old man who has been helping him improve his writing is actually Pulitzer prize winning author William Forrester, a man famous for only ever writing one book. Cast also includes F. Murray Abraham, Anna Paquin, Busta Rhymes and a special cameo appearance by Matt Damon.

results.title: Finding Nemo [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Andrew Stanton, Graham Walters, Pixar Animation Studios and Walt Disney Pictures
results.brief_description: A beautifully colourful and enchanting computer animated feature about a father clown fish, Marlin, searching the vast ocean near Sydney for his lost son, Nemo. Marlin pairs up with Dory (voice provided by comic Ellen DeGeneres) who suffers short-term memory loss and Nemo finds himself in a fish tank in a dentist’s office. The experiences the father and son have provide the viewer with an action-packed, sometimes fearsome and fun-filled adventure. (Please Note: some scenes may frighten young children)

results.title: Finding Nemo
results.creator_credit: Andrew Stanton, Graham Walters, Pixar Animation Studios and Walt Disney Pictures
results.brief_description: When Nemo, a young clownfish, is unexpectedly carried far from home, his father Marlin, and Dory, a friendly but forgetful regal blue tang fish embark on an epic journey. Features the voices of Albert Brooks, Ellen DeGeneres, Alexander Gould, Willem DaFoe, Brad Garrett.

results.title: Final fantasy: the spirits within
results.creator_credit: Hiroonobu Sakaguchi, Motonori Sakakibara, Akio Sakai, Chris Lee, Jun Aida, Columbia Pictures and Square Co
results.brief_description: Based on the Final Fantasy video games, this computer animated feature presents an apocalyptic vision of earth in the not too distant future. The year is 2069; planet earth has now been rendered uninhabitable due to an invasion by a race of phantom like extraterrestrials. What’s left of the human race has now retreated into outer space as they wait and plan a counter-attack against the vicious aliens. Brilliant young scientist Dr. Aki Ross (Ming-Na), is plagued with prophetic dreams about earth’s future. In an attempt to combat the aliens and to find the cure to the deadly ‘alien spirits’ that have infected her body, she joins forces with a prestigious military squad called Deep Eyes. Working with a team of international animators, the filmmakers have managed to create a spectacular if not bleak vision of the future. This is also the first time that animators have attempted to create photo-realistic human characters, meticulously animating every small detail, right down to the movement of each strand of hair on a characters head. Cast voices include Alec Baldwin, James Woods, Donald Sutherland, Ving Rhames and Steve Buscemi.

results.title: Films by Harry Smith = Harry Smith: early abstractions
results.brief_description: Harry Smith, filmmaker, painter, anthropologist, linguist, and more, was a unique artist who believed in the interconnectedness of human existence. An anthropology student who became involved in the early incarnation of the counter-culture movement, Smith is credited with developing ingenious methods of animation, collage techniques, and hand-painting directly onto film. No 1: Hand drawn animation of shapes - the history of the geologic period depicted in three minutes. No 2: Geometric shapes, circles, squares, and dirty dots morph to the sounds of the Beatles’ rocking tune “I wanna hold your hand”. No 3: Batiked animation made up of a complex interlocking of squares and oblongs, criss-crossings, leaping on and off the screen. No 4: Black and white abstractions of dots and grillwork, this short work evokes an urban night on the town. No 5: “III Circular tensions” This colour abstraction pays homage to fellow animator Oskar Fischinger. No 6: Optically printed Pythagoreanism in four movements supported on squares, circles, grillwork, and triangles. No 10: An exposition of Buddhism and the Kaballa in the form of a collage.

results.title: Filming the impossible
results.creator_credit: Aled Vaughan, Leo Dickinson and HTV Limited
results.brief_description: Leo Dickinson is an English cameraman who goes to such lengths as parachuting from 8000 feet or suspending himself from ropes above a gorge to get a better camera angle. This film, narrated by Dickinson, shows footage shot by him in the Himalayas and the Sudan. When a comrade falls 150 feet down a mountain and another nearly drowns in the rapids, Dickinson keeps on filming. Two climbers cling like spiders to a twenty-five degree fall, Dickinson is there too. The footage is so beautifully filmed and well edited that it is hard to believe that it was taken under such bad conditions and without time to erect tripods or wait for the right light. Photographed by Leo Dickinson and edited by Terry Elgar.
